maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new interface to a NIC team.
The Add-NetLbfoTeamNic cmdlet adds a new team interface to the specified NIC team. You can use this cmdlet to add the interfaces to the specified team by specifying the respective VLAN IDs.
You need administrator privileges to use Add-NetLbfoTeamNic.
Specifies the name of the NIC team to which to add a new team interface.
Specifies the VLAN ID of the team interface. VlanID values must meet the criteria 0 ≤ VlanID < 4095. Specify the value 0 to match frames identified with a VLAN ID of 0 or untagged frames.
Specifies the name of the new team interface.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the new team interface.
Specifies the name of the NIC team to which to add a new team interface.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the VLAN ID of the team interface. VlanID values must meet the criteria 0 ≤ VlanID < 4095. Specify the value 0 to match frames identified with a VLAN ID of 0 or untagged frames.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This cmdlet takes no input objects.
This cmdlet produces an MFT_NetLbfoTeamNic object containing the newly created team interface.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a team interface with VLAN ID 42 to the specified team named Team1.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a list of team interfaces.
The Get-NetLbfoTeamNic cmdlet retrieves a list of team interfaces as specified by the input parameters.
Specifies the name (or wildcard pattern) of the team interface.
Specifies the name of the NIC team for which the user wants to enumerate the team interfaces.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the NIC team object whose team interfaces are to be enumerated.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name (or wildcard pattern) of the team interface.
Specifies the name of the NIC team for which the user wants to enumerate the team interfaces.
Specifies the NIC team object whose team interfaces are to be enumerated.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
This cmdlet takes no input objects.
This cmdlet produces an array of MSFT_NetLbfoTeamNic objects corresponding to the query.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get a list of team interfaces associated with Team1
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-NetLbfoTeamNic -Team Team1
Or PS C:\> $teamObj = Get-NetLbfoTeam –Name 'Team1' PS C:\> Get-NetLbfoTeamNic –TeamOfTheTeamNic $teamObj

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of team interfaces for the specified team named Team1.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get a list of team interfaces by name

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of team interfaces whose name contains “VLAN” in any NIC team whose name starts with T.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a team interface from a NIC team.

The Remove-NetLbfoTeamNic cmdlet removes a team interface from the NIC team. The name of a team interface is the team name followed by the VLAN value of this team interface. You can identify a team interface either by its name, its associated VLAN ID, or its default property.

This cmdlet does not remove the team interface created when the team was created. To remove the team interface created when the team was created, you must remove the team by using the Remove-NetLbfoTeam cmdlet.
You need administrator privileges to use Remove-NetLbfoTeamNic.
Specifies the name of the NIC team from which to remove the team interface.
Specifies the VLAN ID of the team interface to remove.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the object which contains the team interface to remove.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

By default, this cmdlet produces no output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes a team interface named Team1 – VLAN 42 from the team “Team1”.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets a new VLAN id on a team interface, or restores the interface to Default mode.
The Set-NetLbfoTeamNic cmdlet sets the optional values on a team interface. Only the team interface that was created when the team was created can be set to Default mode.
You need administrator privileges to use Set-NetLbfoTeamNic.
Specifies the name of the team interface to modify.
Specifies the name of the NIC team for which to modify the team interface.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Indicates that the team interface should be restored to Default mode.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the VLAN ID of the team interface to modify.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command modifies the current VLAN ID of the team interface named “Team1 – VLAN 42” to the specified VLAN ID 15.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Set the VLAN ID of the primary interface to 5, and then revert it to default
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Set-NetLbfoTeamNic -Name Team1 -VlanID 5
This command changes the primary team interface, “Team1 – VLAN 5” to default mode. PS C:\> Set-NetLbfoTeamNic –Name "Team1 – VLAN 5" –Default

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the VLAN ID of the primary team interface named Team1 to 5.
